title: 105_hr4046
content: Restrictions on transfers or discharges of nursing facility residents in case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program. In case of a nursing facility voluntarily withdrawing from the Medicaid program, residents cannot be transferred or discharged solely based on the facility's withdrawal. Residents of a nursing facility cannot be transferred or discharged solely due to the facility's withdrawal from the Medicaid program. The provisions of this section apply to existing residents until their discharge, and new residents after the withdrawal date. The facility must provide oral and written notice to new residents about important information upon their admission, and obtain a signed acknowledgment of receipt from each individual. The facility must provide written notice to new residents about important information, signed by the individual, separate from other documents. This does not affect any requirement for advance notice of termination. The facility must inform new residents in writing that it may discharge them if they are unable to pay, even if they become eligible for medical assistance. The facility can discharge residents who are unable to pay, even if they become eligible for medical assistance. Despite voluntary withdrawal from participation under the State plan, the facility's agreement continues for such residents. After voluntarily withdrawing from the State plan, the facility must still comply with all requirements and maintain survey and enforcement authority for nursing facility services provided to residents. The facility must comply with survey, certification, and enforcement authority even after voluntarily withdrawing from the State plan. This includes provisions for significant reductions in participation for residents entitled to medical assistance. The facility must comply with survey, certification, and enforcement authority even after voluntarily withdrawing from the State plan. This applies to residents entitled to medical assistance under this title for nursing facility services. The paragraph does not apply to new residents starting residence in a facility after a certain date. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to voluntary withdrawals from participation occurring after the enactment date. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report to Congress on the impact of the implementation of the amendment on nursing facilities, residents, and Medicaid beneficiaries within 5 years of the enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report to Congress within 5 years of the enactment date on the impact of changes in Medicaid reimbursement rates for nursing facility services. The report will analyze the extent to which nursing facilities withdraw from the Medicaid program and make recommendations for legislative changes.
